bib.title: Cross sections of ground and isomeric states for (n,p)reaction on Sm-154 between 13.57 and 14.83 MeV neutrons

free_txt: SAMES T-400 neutron generator with
Fast Sample Transfer System(FSTS), delivering a
sample from irradiation position to HPGe detector
within 0.5 sec.
Beam current is kept at about 300 microA with
accelerator voltage of 250 kV.
M.M.
For dead time and the self-absorption of the gamma ray
in the pellet(4%).
Neutron flux was corrected for the neutron flux
variations.
The effects of coincidence summing and random
coincidences were neglected because the measurements
were carried out at a long distance 160 mm from the
detector.
For the self-absorption of gamma rays in the sample
and monitor as well as the beta absorber;  gamma-ray
attenuations determined experimentally were found to be
up to 1% and 2% for all the pellets and the beta
absorber, respectively.
For low energy neutron contribution to the investigated
reactions - up to 10% of the total neutron spectrum.
The effect of low energy neutron in sample pellets
packed in thin polyethylene boxes was performed by the
MCNP5 Monte Carlo code (X-5MonteCarloTeam,2003) and
found less than 1% that can be neglected.
During irradiation of Al, the neutron flux was
monitored with plastic scintillation detector NE102A,
placed under the neutron-producing target. The monitor
was calibrated with the standard reaction irradiating
Al2O3 sample placed in the same irradiation position.
During irradiation of Sm, the neutrons were monitored
by NE102E detector (MCS mode).
HPGe Detector (Canberra, 82 cm3, 1.79 keV(FWHM)
resolution at 1.333 MeV) at 160 mm from detector - to
measure gamma activities induced in Al and Sm samples.
An acrylic plate of 10 mm thickness was placed in front
of the detector in order to eliminate the beta-gamma
summing effect.
The total efficiency was determined using the
single-line nuclides of 241Am (60 keV), 109Cd (88 keV),
60Co (1173+1332 keV) with 3% error.
SAMES T-400 neutron generator with
Fast Sample Transfer System(FSTS), delivering a
sample from irradiation position to HPGe detector
within 0.5 sec.
Beam current is kept at about 300 microA with
accelerator voltage of 250 kV.
Deuteron beam current 350 microA.
The irradiation positions at the angles to the deuteron
beam were 0, 30, 60, 90, 120, corresponding to the
The effective energy of incident neutron at each
irradiation position were determined by the ratio of
and 93Nb(n,2n)92mNb (10.15 d) (Nethaway,1978) reaction
cross sections (the Zr/Nb ratio method) (Lewis and
Zieba, 1980) and are given in detail in Subasi+,1996.
Neutron fluxes are measured in each irradiation place
(70mm from the neutron source )from 7.0+7 to 1.0E+
n/cm2*s, depending on the neutron target condition.
Cyclic irradiation. 10 cycles.
Al standard sample irradiation - 30 min.
Decay gamma-rays.
Details of method.
Details of method.
Details of method.
90Zr(n,2n)89Zr c-s data used in ZR/Nb method.
93Nb(n,2n)92mNb c-s data used in ZR/Nb method.
Zr/Nb ratio method .
Sample pellets(13mm diameter,8.5mm thickness, about 2g
weight) were pressed from the high-purity (99.9%) Sm2O3
and Al2O3 powders. Water contents were removed by
heating up to 105 deg C, then 0.5h cooled down to the
room temperature, were filled in dry stainless steel
capsules, pressed to form a dense pellet, were tightly
packed into thin polyethylene(PE) boxes and sealed-of.
Full energy peak (FEP) area, mass of sample,
the concentration of the element, Avogadro number,the
atomic weight of the element, isotopic abundance, the
relative gamma-ray intensity, effective flux measured
by calibrated Al foil monitor, counting solid angle
with self-absorption correction, FEP efficiency of the
gamma-ray detector, decay constant, the number of
cycles were used to cross-section calculation by the
cyclic activation formula using the one-cycle time as
sum of irradiation, delay, counting, return times.
Compared with statistical model calculations by
the code TALYS.

isotopic abundance: 75.+-0.29 -> 22.75+-0.29.

Concentration of the element.

photo-peak area).
Neutron flux fluctuation.
Effective neutron flux
(reference cross-section).
Coincidence summing
irradiation, cooling and measuring times.
Uncertainties were assumed to be uncorrelated.
The total uncertainty could be determined by adding the
experimental errors and the uncertainties of nuclear
data in the quadratic form.
